newsitem.title: CANADA: Quebec to boost pension plan premiums to 9.9 pct.
newsitem.headline: Quebec to boost pension plan premiums to 9.9 pct.

text.p: The Quebec government said on Thursday it plans to increase provincial pension fund premiums to 9.9 percent by 2003 from the current six percent.
Quebec Labour minister Louise Harel said the increases would guarantee equity between payouts made by "baby boomers" and coming generations.
The measures will ensure that the plan's reserve fund by 2020 will be five-and-a-half times higher than annual pension payments made to Quebec's retired residents.

Quebec's action follows a similar move by the federal government which announced in February plans to bump up Canada Pension Plan (CCP) premium rates to 9.9 percent of insurable earnings from 5.85 percent. The premiums are paid equally by employee and employee.
Ottawa's plan was criticized by some analysts as being a big tax grab.

Unlike the other Canadian provinces, Quebec manages its own pension plan. Funds contributed helped create the province's C$57 billion pension manager Caisse de depot et placement, which is Canada's most powerful institutional investor.
Quebec did not indicate how much additional money it expects to pump into the pension fund with the premium hike, but officials said the amount was in the billions of dollars.
In 2030, more than 46 percent of Quebeckers will be aged 65 years and over, officials said. In 1996, 20 percent of Quebec's 7.1 million population was 65 or older.
